With Thievery Trade Proficiency, you can do the following:

  • Pick Pocket: You can attempt to pickpocket someone without being noticed by making a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) and Dexterity (Stealth) check and taking the lower result. The target DC is the target’s Awareness, modified by the difficulty of the targeted item as determined by the GM. If you roll higher than the DC, then you successfully take the item unnoticed.
    • Any items that would cause a noticeable weight difference to the creature if stolen, such as a sheathed sword or hefty coin purse, causes the target to roll a Wisdom (Perception) check. If the result is higher than the target’s Awareness, then that is the target DC to beat instead. However, even should they fail to notice this at first, they are likely to notice it soon after.

The Thievery Kit can be used in the following ways:

  • Pick Lock: Thievery Kits come with varying lockpicking tools, allowing you to attempt to pick a basic lock using a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check without garnering disadvantage.

If you have Thievery Trade Proficiency, you can use the Thievery Kit in the following ways: 

  • Capable Pickpocket: When you use Pick Pocket, you do not have to roll the Dexterity (Stealth) check.
  • Capable Locksmith: When you use Pick Lock, you can additionally attempt to pick complex locks without disadvantage.
  • Cut Purse: When you use Pick Pocket, you can make the Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check at advantage and can take a Disengage action as a minor action. Regardless of the result, however, your crime is immediately spotted.
  • Arm or Disarm Trap: You can attempt to arm or disarm a trap without setting it off by rolling a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check without disadvantage.
  • Appraise Item: As a Rest Action, you can determine the estimated sale value of up to three items for an area you have spent at least a day in.
